webTitle: UK services sector expands in May

fields.standfirst: Analysts say the relatively upbeat reading on the services PMI makes a new bout of quantitative easing less likely when the Bank of England makes its decision at noon
fields.body:
Hopes that the Bank of England would unleash a fresh round of quantitative easing have been dampened by a key survey of the services sector, which showed a healthy expansion in May, despite the deteriorating situation in the eurozone.

Analysts said the relatively upbeat reading on the services PMI, one of the many pieces of data watched closely by the Bank of England, made a new bout of QE less likely when the nine-member monetary policy committee announces its decision later on Thursday.

The Purchasing Managers' Index remained unchanged at 53.3 for last month - safely above the 50-mark that separates expansion from contraction. The strong showing contrasted with a sharp drop in confidence among manufacturers.

However, analysts said that with construction also weak, there was little sign that the recession-hit UK is bouncing back strongly. "It's hard to get away from the fact that the UK economy remains relatively fragile," said Paul Smith, economist at Markit, which compiles the survey. He added that transport and communications firms had seen strong output, whereas financial services - heavily exposed to the turmoil in the eurozone - had stagnated.

Howard Archer, of consultancy IHS Global Insight, said: "Given the dominant role of the services sector in the economy, the steady growth in May reported by the purchasing managers is welcome news and supports hopes that it can avoid further contraction in the second quarter, even though it is handicapped by the extra day's public holiday resulting from the Queen's Diamond jubilee."

He added that the latest British Retail Consortium survey, released on Thursday morning, had also suggested that May was a better month than rain-soaked April.

The Bank conceded in its last quarterly inflation report that inflation was likely to stay higher, for longer, than it had previously thought. But the PMI survey also showed that costs in the services sector were rising at the slowest pace since 2009, suggesting that inflationary pressures may be easing.

The MPC will announce the results of its two-day monthly policy meeting at noon. The City consensus is for no change, but a growing number of experts had begun to forecast an expansion in the £325bn total the Bank has spent on quantitative easing, as well as a possible cut in interest rates from their record low of 0.5%, to contain the fallout from the eurozone sovereign debt crisis.

webTitle: FTSE opens up after impressive Wednesday rally

fields.standfirst:
All eyes on Thursday BoE interest rate decision
Johnson Matthey leads the market but the miners take a hit
fields.body:
Following on from yesterday's impressive rally the markets continued their steady increase, albeit at a slightly more muted level.

The FTSE 100 is up 25 points, 0.5%, at 5409 while across Europe, the French, German, Spanish and Italian markets were all up slightly.

Eyes will be trained on the Bank of England today, as the Monetary Policy Committee announces its latest interest rate decision – expected to remain unchanged at 0.5%, despite some calls to lower in even further.

Any excitement for further QE by the BoE bods will be sated after figures show Britain's service sector grew faster than expected in May.

But some will hope there are no such compulsions in the US, with Fed chief Ben Bernanke addressing the US Congress this afternoon.

Alternatively, it could all be a damp squib and the wait-and-see brigade will continue unabated.

In company news, the biggest cheer could be heard by Johnson Matthey shareholders after the world's largest catalytic converter maker announced its first special dividend, 100p per share, on top of the full-year dividend at 55p, up 20%, following better-than-expected full year results.

They were followed up by chavs-to-riches clothing company Burberry Group, which has turned around its once dented image to become one of the biggest fashion houses in the country, with shares up 35p, 2.6%, to £13.58. It comes thanks to a positive broker note by Credit Suisse, raising the business from "neutral" to "outperform".

Biggest fallers were the miners Fresnillo, down 48p, 3.3%, to £14.25, and Randgold Resources, down 125p, 2.1%, at £58.55, but both have made strong gains in recent weeks.

Elsewhere, Tullow Oil has found "good quality light oil" in its deepwater well in the waters around the Ivory Coast. The news has boosted its shares up 35p, 2.4%, to £14.72.

webTitle: George Osborne 'optimistic' on Spanish banking crisis

fields.standfirst: Chancellor says he believes solution is imminent, but calls for 'harmonisation' of fiscal policies to secure single currency
fields.body:
George Osborne has said he is optimistic that a solution to the Spanish banking crisis is imminent but has pressed for "greater harmonisation" of fiscal and banking policies in the eurozone to secure the single currency in the long term.

The chancellor made his comments as David Cameron called for a "whole series" of measures to stabilise the single currency area as he prepared to travel to Berlin to meet Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, on Thursday.

Osborne told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme that the eurozone need "to sort out immediately" the situation in the Spanish banking system as the country's prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, came under mounting international pressure to accept the eurozone's fourth national bailout in two years.

Rajoy is calling for a direct eurozone rescue of his country's banks to avoid the bailout.

Osborne said the decision on whether to use bailout funds to directly recapitalise Spanish banks was "a matter for the Spanish government and the eurozone". Though he was not directly party to discussion, he was optimistic that eurozone finance ministers had identified the problem and were "working hard on an imminent solution".

But he warned that "more permanent changes" were needed because bringing stability to the Spanish banking system was "not going to end the instability in the eurozone".

Further action, including greater banking and fiscal harmonisation, was necessary to resolve the wider problem, he said. But Britain would require certain safeguards if there was a "full-blown banking union".

Laying out his views on the measures needed for a resolution, he said: "I think you would need to sort out immediately the situation in the Spanish banking system, and the uncertainty there. Basically put money into the Spanish banking system to recapitalise it without worsening the Spanish sovereign debt situation."

Another factor in the mix was the election in Greece in a week's time which needed to result in "parties committed to Greece's euro membership and the steps necessary to stay in the EU", said Osborne.

"And then I think you need to put in place in pretty short order the things that are going to make the single currency work on a medium- to long-term basis and that includes a greater harmonisation, or a greater integration of fiscal policies, of banking policies. All the things that single currencies like the pound and the dollar in the UK and the US have, as features of stable currencies."

Osborne said the "remorseless logic" of the single currency would lead towards a banking and financial services union, with "tougher pan-eurozone supervision". But he insisted there was "no way" Britain would be part of that because of the loss of national sovereignty involved and stressed that the UK would demand safeguards.

"It's clearly going to be a challenge developing, within a single market of 27 member states of which Britain is one, a banking union of 17 eurozone members. They need to do that to make their currency work and it's massively in Britain's interest that the currency works, because an unstable euro does enormous damage to jobs and growth in Britain.

"I think Britain will require, if there is a full-blown banking union, certain safeguards, and indeed, if you cast your mind back to last December, and the European council where David Cameron vetoed the fiscal compact that was put before us, he was asking for safeguards on banking and financial services.

"I think we were ahead of the game there – we were identifying a potential issue for the UK, which is do we want, as Europe's largest financial centre, to have a banking union on our doorstep without certain safeguards that ensure that the single market in financial services still operates at 27 and Britain still has a big say on regulation as it affects all member states."

The prime minister flew from Oslo to meet the German chancellor as she comes under growing pressure to put German taxpayers' money behind measures such as "eurobonds" which would spread the burden of debt from ailing economies like Greece among the 17 single currency members.

Cameron is expected to say that he and the US president, Barack Obama, are agreed that an "immediate plan" is needed to save the eurozone and warned on Wednesday night that "speed is of the essence" if jobs, opportunities and growth are not to be lost.

Speaking in Oslo, Cameron said: "I don't think we should single out one eurozone leader and put all the responsibility on them. There is a whole series of steps that need to be taken."

The prime minister faced calls for a referendum to decide whether Britain stays in the European Union or throw off the "shackles" as the spectre of closer integration to save the eurozone risked forcing the EU closer to a "single country called Europe".

Lord Owen, a former Labour foreign secretary who went on to lead the SDP, used a column in the Times to suggest a national poll to give voters a say on whether Britain would be better off leaving the EU to join a new, wider single market.

Owen told Today: "I think the country feel cheated that they didn't have the promised referendum on the Lisbon Treaty and I think as we watch more and more integration coming, greater and greater political, fiscal and banking union, the European Union is changing and the British government now needs to lift its voice. We've been generous about making these changes to keep the eurozone successful and that's right but we want to hear what they are going to do to safeguard the single market. We need a single market without a single government, that's the British position and I think it's a good many other countries in Europe as well."

Pressed on his comments, Osborne told Today that any transfer of power from Britain to the EU would trigger a referendum under legislation put in place by the coalition government.
